attributes.title: Linking persons with HIV, discharged from jail, with community care: a direct comparison of the costs and effects of three HIV management strategies in the District of Columbia Department of Corrections
attributes.description: Does the manner in which a patient entering jail is tested for HIV affect linkage to HIV care (if infected) or PrEP (if negative)?

summary.value: This is a registration of study plans before data collection begins. The attached file contains the protocol.

registration_responses.summary: This is a registration of study plans before data collection begins. The attached file contains the protocol.

attributes.title: Interventions influencing the dietary consumption of animal-based products: An overview of reviews
attributes.description:
Review question(s)
1) What interventions influence the dietary consumption of animal-based products?
  1a) What does the combined information from all systematic reviews indicate?
  1b) How well do current systematic reviews use best-practice approaches?
  1c) What gaps exist in the review-level literature?

summary.value: This registration serves as an a priori research protocol for an overview of reviews investigating interventions to reduce animal consumption. It differs from the other registration attached to this project in that it does not specify ScienceDirect as a database for searching.

data.name: Reducing animal consumption - overview of reviews protocol.pdf

extra.selectedFileName: Reducing animal consumption - overview of reviews protocol.pdf

registration_responses.summary: This registration serves as an a priori research protocol for an overview of reviews investigating interventions to reduce animal consumption. It differs from the other registration attached to this project in that it does not specify ScienceDirect as a database for searching.

uploader.file_name: Reducing animal consumption - overview of reviews protocol.pdf

attributes.title: EEGLAB datasets for study of event-related potentials during categorization of emotionally-charged and neutral visual scenes in carriers of  polymorphisms of the COMT, HTR2A, BDNF genes
attributes.description: Datasets of this project are ERP-recordings which were made during the study aimed to discover the association between parameters of the event-related potentials and categorization of images of visual scenes, both emotionally-charged and neutral, in carriers of polymorphisms of the COMT, HTR2A, BDNF genes

summary.value: Datasets of this project are ERP-recordings which were made during the study aimed to discover the association between parameters of the event-related potentials and categorization of images of visual scenes, both emotionally-charged and neutral, in carriers of polymorphisms of the COMT, HTR2A, BDNF genes.

registration_responses.summary: Datasets of this project are ERP-recordings which were made during the study aimed to discover the association between parameters of the event-related potentials and categorization of images of visual scenes, both emotionally-charged and neutral, in carriers of polymorphisms of the COMT, HTR2A, BDNF genes.

q1.value: Spatial learning with or without prior task experience

q3.value:
Although ignoring visual distractions is paramount to efficient attentional selection, recent behavioral studies demonstrate that suppression is not under volitional control, but only appears to emerge when distractor information can be derived directly from experience, through statistical learning. For example, observers can (implicitly) learn the most probable distractor location, which in turn reduces distractor interference during search. While there is general agreement that this involves spatial suppression, it remains unclear whether this suppression is distractor blind, as observed in some studies, or specific to distractors as observed in others. One prerequisite for spatial suppression to be generic appears to be that subjects are in a so-called singleton detection mode (i.e., they cannot create an attentional set on either the target or distractor level, but instead search for the unique shape in the display). Here we examine the idea that in addition, subjects should also not have had prior experience with the task. Specifically, we expect feature blind suppression to emerge when the spatial regularity is introduced at the start of the experiment, but not when it is introduced in the second half and subjects have gained experience with the task. 

In this experiment, observers searched for a unique shape (e.g., diamond among circles) in displays that could contain salient distractors appearing on one location more frequently (i.e., high probability distractor location). Critically, this high probability distractor location was either only present in the first half of the experiment, or in the second half of the experiment.

q4.value:
a)	When a spatial regularity is introduced at the start of the experiment, learned spatial suppression is feature blind such that distractors are suppressed and target selection is impaired at the high probability distractor location
b)	When a spatial regularity is introduced after observers have been familiarized with the task, learned spatial suppression is distractor specific such that distractors are suppressed, but target selection is no longer impaired at the high probability distractor location

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This is a within subjects design. The experiment consists of a single session. The experiment contains 20 blocks of 56 trials. Participants search for the unique shape in a display. In 71% the trials the search display contains a singleton distractor. In half of the experiment (first of second half; order counterbalanced) this distractor appears with a higher probability (65%) on a specific location than on all other locations. Across all trials the target is still equally likely to appear at all locations.

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

question.value: Participants will be recruited via subjects pool of the VU (vu.sona-systems.com)  Participants will be paid 8E an hour or receive research credits for participation. Participants must  have normal or corrected to normal vision.

q13.value: Testing will continue until we reach a complete dataset of 48 subjects. Subjects that need to be excluded will be replaced (see data exclusion)

q14.value: This study builds on previous experiments using 18 - 24 participants. Although we are using a within-subjects design to test a crucial prediction (i.e., feature blind spatial suppression will only arise when the spatial regularity is introduced at the start of the experiment) we can only use data of half of the participants. Therefore we chose a final sample of 48 subjects.

question.value: We manipulated the location of the distractor, which was either equally likely on all display locations (first or second half of the experiment; order counterbalanced), or appeared with 65% probability at one of the display locations (first or second half of the experiment; order counterbalanced)
Behavioral outcome variables will be target detection reaction times (i.e., time between search display onset and response) and response accuracy. These are measured via keyboard responses.
We will take the mean of single trial data per condition to summarize RT and accuracy data

RT and accuracy are analyzed using separate repeated-measures ANOVAs, followed by planned pairwise comparisons using t-tests.

1)	Distractor costs: A repeated measures ANOVA using only data from no spatial bias blocks with within subjects factors Order (first half, second half), Distractor (present, absent)
2)	Distractor learning: A repeated measures ANOVA with factors Spatial bias (yes, no), Distractor Location (high, low). In this analysis, trials in no spatial bias blocks will be artificially coded as high and low probable. 
3)	Target impairment: The same analysis as in 2, but now tuned to targets at high or low probable distractor locations. 

As it is an open question how long learned spatial biases will persists after the statistical regularity is removed, analysis 2 and 3 will also be conducted with the factor Order as a between subjects factor. And finally, the data from the first and second half of the experiment will be analyzed separately.

q21.value: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining if the ANOVA and the planned comparisons are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct.

q22.value:
Behavioral preprocessing
- Subjects with overall error rates or RTs that are more than 2.5 SD away from the group mean are excluded 
- RT analysis is limited to correct trials 
- for RT analysis we will use a two step trimming procedure 
- first RTs smaller than 200 are excluded 
- Next data are trimmed on the basis of a cut off value 2.5 SD from the mean per participant

q23.value: If a subject does not complete the experiment that subject will be replaced by a new subject

q24.value: We will explore how long the spatial biases persist by binning data (e.g., groups of 10 trials: 1-10, 11-20, etc). and then contrast high and low probability locations separately for distractors and targets

q25.value: The hypothesis in this preregistraction are largely inspired by preliminary results from the EEG: predictive vs unpredictive features component in this project

attributes.title: Basic need satisfaction in parents and children
attributes.description: This project aims to longitudinally examine the interplay between parents’ own basic need satisfaction (BNS), their perception of their child’s BNS, and their child’s self-reported BNS.

q1.value: Basic psychological need satisfaction in parents and children: examination of their interplay over time

q2.value: Vanessa Kurdi, Noriaki Fukuzumi, Ryo Ishii, Ayame Tamura, Naoki Nakazato, Kazuhiro Ohtani, Shin-ichi Ishikawa, Michiko Sakaki, Kou Murayama, Ayumi Tanaka

q3.value:
The Self-Determination Theory posits that all humans have three basic psychological needs: autonomy, competence, and relatedness (Ryan & Deci, 2017). Humans feel autonomous when they voluntarily act in accordance with their own interests and values. They feel competent when they have mastery and can effectively attain their goals. Lastly, their need for relatedness is fulfilled when they feel connected to others. Basic need satisfaction (BNS) is important, as it is associated not only with optimal development and well-being, but also with the development of greater relationships (Ryan & Deci, 2017). Close relationship partners who report greater basic need satisfaction correspondingly report greater well-being and a more satisfying relationship of higher quality (e.g., Deci et al., 2006; Patrick et al., 2007). In any close relationship, the BNS of one individual is thought to influence the BNS of the other individual. Findings from the student-teacher relationship literature support this effect, as teachers’ BNS has been associated with students’ BNS through the use of autonomy supportive teaching practices (e.g., Roth et al., 2007). However, little is known about the interplay between parent and child BNS. Some studies have found that parents’ BNS is correlated with their child’s BNS through their need-fulfilling parenting practices (e.g., Wuyts et al., 2018), but to our knowledge, no study has yet examined their interplay over time. Furthermore, parents’ perception of their child’s BNS could also play a role in the dynamic between parent and child BNS, just as teachers are influenced by their perception of their students (e.g., Skinner & Belmont, 1993). Therefore, this project aims to longitudinally examine the interplay between parents’ own BNS, their perception of their child’s BNS, and their child’s self-reported BNS. 

In a first study, we have examined the interplay of parent and child BNS over two time points in a sample of 200 Japanese dyads. Results from cross-lagged models have shown that parents’ self-reported T1 BNS was not significantly associated with their child’s self-reported T2 BNS, with the exception of a tendency noted for the association between parents’ T1 and children’s T2 autonomy need satisfaction. Children’s self-reported T1 BNS also did not predict their parent’s self-reported T2 BNS. Parents’ perception of their child’s T1 BNS was found to positively predict their child’s self-reported T2 BNS, while children’s self-reported T1 BNS surprisingly did not significantly predict their parents’ perception of their T2 BNS. Only one exception was found, as children’s competence need satisfaction at T1 negatively and significantly predicted their parent’s perception of their competence need satisfaction at T2.

For our second study, we now want to replicate some of our main findings in a larger sample: (1) the association between parents’ T1 and children’s T2 autonomy satisfaction need, and (2) the association between parents’ perceptions of their child’s BNS at T1 and their child’s self-reported BNS at T2. Furthermore, in order to explain these findings, we will test whether the associations are mediated by autonomy-supportive parenting practices, or their opposite, controlling parenting practices, which are determining parenting practices according to the self-determination theory.

q4.value:
1. Parents’ BNS at T1 will positively predict their child’s self-reported BNS at T2, at least for autonomy need satisfaction.
2. Parents’ perceptions of their child’s BNS at T1 will positively predict their child’s self-reported BNS at T2.
3. Associations between (1) parents’ BNS and children’s BNS and (2) parents’ perception of their child’s BNS and children’s BNS will be mediated by parents’ use of autonomy-supportive or controlling practices. We predict that at least one of the two parenting practices will mediate the associations in the following ways: 
         a. Parents who report higher BNS will use more autonomy-supportive and less controlling practices, which will be associated with higher BNS in their child.
         b. Parents who report lower BNS will use more controlling and less autonomy-supportive practices, which will be associated with lower BNS in their child.
         c. Parents who perceive their child to have higher BNS will use more autonomy-supportive and less controlling practices, which will in turn lead to the report of greater BNS from their child. 
         d. Parents who perceive their child to have lower BNS will use more controlling and less autonomy-supportive practices, which will in turn lead to the report of lower levels of BNS from their child.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Longitudinal observational study with two time points.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q11.value: Data for the first time point of the study was already collected by a private research firm in 2019, but we do not have access to it yet. The data from the second time point has not been fully collected yet. We will have access to the whole dataset once the second time point is collected.

question.value: Participants were recruited from a large nationwide database managed by a private Japanese research firm. The database includes participants recruited through nationwide newspapers and news magazines ads. Participants were randomly selected from different parts of Japan, with no regional restrictions. Children needed to be between 13 and 15 years of age. The project was explained over the phone to parents and consent was obtained for their own and their child’s participation. Participants were mailed their first questionnaire in October 2019 (T1) and asked to return them. They will be mailed a second questionnaire in February-March 2020 (T2) to return once completed. Parents and adolescents were and will be instructed to fill out their questionnaire independently and not to look at each other’s answers. All participants receive monetary compensation for their participation.

q13.value: The sample size for the second study was fixed at 400 parent-child dyads (800 individuals) for the first time point. We aimed to recruit equal numbers of male and female adolescents.

q14.value: The sample size was chosen to recruit as many participants as allowed by the funding received to run the study. The funding allowed the recruitment of 400 dyads at T1. We also considered the possible loss of participants between the two time points. Based on our first study, we expect an attrition rate of 25% between the first and second time points which would give us an anticipated total of 300 dyads at T2.

question.value:
Basic Psychological Need Satisfaction. Parents reported their own and their child’s level of basic psychological need satisfaction by answering the satisfaction subscale from the Japanese version of the Basic Psychological Need Satisfaction and Frustration Scale (Nishimura & Suzuki, 2016) twice – once about themselves and once about their perception of their child’s need satisfaction. Adolescents reported their own need satisfaction by filling out the same scale. The scale contains four items for the satisfaction of each basic psychological need: competence (e.g., “I feel confident that I can do things well”), autonomy (e.g., “I feel my choices express who I really am”), and relatedness (e.g., “I feel connected with the people who care for me, and for whom I care”). The items are answered on a 5-point Likert scale, going from “1 – Completely disagree” to “5 – Completely agree”. 

Parental Autonomy Support and Control. Children reported their perception of their parents’ autonomy support and control by filling out a Japanese translation of the Perceived Parental Autonomy Support Scale (P-PASS; Mageau et al., 2015). Parents also reported their own autonomy-supportive or controlling practices with their child by filling out the same questionnaire. The P-PASS contains 12 items about autonomy support (e.g., “My parents encouraged me to be myself”) and 12 items about psychological control (e.g., “My parents used guilt to control me”). The items are answered on a 7-point Likert scale, going from “1 – Do not agree at all” to “7 – Very strongly agree”.

Family Socioeconomic Status. Parents reported the annual income of the family at T1 by answering one homemade question. 

Sex. Parents and adolescents reported their own sex at T1 by answering one homemade question.

Age. Parents reported their age on a homemade question at T1. Adolescents reported their date of birth at T1, from which their age was calculated.
The items of each scale or subscale will be combined into latent variables in the statistical models.

All analyses will be performed with the statistical software R (R Core Team, 2018). To answer our three hypotheses, we will run cross-lagged models with mediations in which parents’ BNS, their perception of their child’s BNS, and their child’s self-reported BNS at T1 will predict the same variables at T2. The mediation analyses in our cross-lagged models will test the mediation effect of autonomy-supportive and controlling practices as reported by the children on the associations between parents’ BNS and children’s BNS, and the associations between parents’ perception of their child’s BNS and their child’s self-reported BNS. We will follow the analytic strategy described by Cole and Maxwell (2003) and Little et al. (2007), and applied in Weinstein et al. (2017) and Ohtani et al. (2019), to run mediation analyses in two-waves datasets. We will run a separate model for each basic psychological need, for a total of three models with equality constraints across time points and informants. For each model, we will also control for family socioeconomic status, as well as the age and sex of parents and adolescents.

q21.value: For all analyses, we will use the following indices to judge the fit of our models: the Root Mean Square Error of Approximation (RMSEA), the Standardised Root Mean Square Residual (SRMR), the Comparative Fit Index (CFI), and the Tucker-Lewis Index (TLI). For a good fit, the RMSEA and the SRMR should be lower than .08, and the CFI and TLI should be over .90 (Little, 2013). To judge the significance of our betas, we will also use the standard .05 threshold for p-values.

q23.value: We will use full-information likelihood to manage all missing data.

q24.value: We will also test the mediation of the associations with the measure of autonomy-supportive and controlling practices reported by the parents.

q25.value:
References

Cole, D. A., & Maxwell, S. E. (2003). Testing Mediational Models With Longitudinal Data: Questions and Tips in the Use of Structural Equation Modeling. Journal of Abnormal Psychology, 112(4), 558–577. https://doi.org/10.1037/0021-843X.112.4.558
Deci, E. L., La Guardia, J. G., Moller, A. C., Scheiner, M. J., & Ryan, R. M. (2006). On the Benefits of Giving as Well as Receiving Autonomy Support: Mutuality in Close Friendships. Personality and Social Psychology Bulletin, 32(3), 313–327. https://doi.org/10.1177/0146167205282148
Little, T. D. (2013). Longitudinal structural equation modeling. The Guildford Press.
Little, T. D., Preacher, K. J., Selig, J. P., & Card, N. A. (2007). New developments in latent variable panel analyses of longitudinal data. International Journal of Behavioral Development, 31(4), 357–365. https://doi.org/10.1177/0165025407077757
Mageau, G. A., Ranger, F., Joussemet, M., Koestner, R., Moreau, E., & Forest, J. (2015). Validation of the Perceived Parental Autonomy Support Scale (P-PASS). Canadian Journal of Behavioural Science / Revue Canadienne Des Sciences Du Comportement, 47(3), 251–262. https://doi.org/10.1037/a0039325
Nishimura, T., & Suzuki, T. (2016). Basic Psychological Need Satisfaction and Frustration in Japan: Controlling for the Big Five Personality Traits. Japanese Psychological Research, 58(4), 320–331. https://doi.org/10.1111/jpr.12131
Ohtani, K., Murayama, K., Ishii, R., Fukuzumi, N., Sakaki, M., Ishikawa, S., Suzuki, T., & Tanaka, A. (2019). Parental Motivational Perseverance Predicts Adolescents’ Depressive Symptoms: An Intergenerational Analysis with Actor-Partner Interdependence Model. Journal of Youth and Adolescence. https://doi.org/10.1007/s10964-019-01083-2
Patrick, H., Knee, C. R., Canevello, A., & Lonsbary, C. (2007). The role of need fulfillment in relationship functioning and well-being: A self-determination theory perspective. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, 92(3), 434–457. https://doi.org/10.1037/0022-3514.92.3.434
R Core Team. (2018). R: A Language and Environment for Statistical Computing. R Foundation for Statistical Computing. https://www.R-project.org
Roth, G., Assor, A., Kanat-Maymon, Y., & Kaplan, H. (2007). Autonomous motivation for teaching: How self-determined teaching may lead to self-determined learning. Journal of Educational Psychology, 99(4), 761–774. https://doi.org/10.1037/0022-0663.99.4.761
Ryan, R. M., & Deci, E. L. (2017). Self-determination theory: Basic psychological needs in motivation, development, and wellness. The Guildford Press.
Skinner, E. A., & Belmont, M. J. (1993). Motivation in the classroom: Reciprocal effects of teacher behavior and student engagement across the school year. Journal of Educational Psychology, 85(4), 571–581. https://doi.org/10.1037/0022-0663.85.4.571
Weinstein, N., Przybylski, A. K., & Murayama, K. (2017). A prospective study of the motivational and health dynamics of Internet Gaming Disorder. PeerJ, 5, e3838. https://doi.org/10.7717/peerj.3838
Wuyts, D., Soenens, B., Vansteenkiste, M., & Van Petegem, S. (2018). The role of observed autonomy support, reciprocity, and need satisfaction in adolescent disclosure about friends. Journal of Adolescence, 65, 141–154. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.adolescence.2018.03.012

registration_responses.q1: Basic psychological need satisfaction in parents and children: examination of their interplay over time
registration_responses.q2: Vanessa Kurdi, Noriaki Fukuzumi, Ryo Ishii, Ayame Tamura, Naoki Nakazato, Kazuhiro Ohtani, Shin-ichi Ishikawa, Michiko Sakaki, Kou Murayama, Ayumi Tanaka
registration_responses.q3:
The Self-Determination Theory posits that all humans have three basic psychological needs: autonomy, competence, and relatedness (Ryan & Deci, 2017). Furthermore, in order to explain these findings, we will test whether the associations are mediated by autonomy-supportive parenting practices, or their opposite, controlling parenting practices, which are determining parenting practices according to the self-determination theory.
registration_responses.q4:
1. Parents’ BNS at T1 will positively predict their child’s self-reported BNS at T2, at least for autonomy need satisfaction.
2. Parents’ perceptions of their child’s BNS at T1 will positively predict their child’s self-reported BNS at T2.
3. Associations between (1) parents’ BNS and children’s BNS and (2) parents’ perception of their child’s BNS and children’s BNS will be mediated by parents’ use of autonomy-supportive or controlling practices. We predict that at least one of the two parenting practices will mediate the associations in the following ways: 
         a. Parents who report higher BNS will use more autonomy-supportive and less controlling practices, which will be associated with higher BNS in their child.
         b. Parents who report lower BNS will use more controlling and less autonomy-supportive practices, which will be associated with lower BNS in their child.
         c. Parents who perceive their child to have higher BNS will use more autonomy-supportive and less controlling practices, which will in turn lead to the report of greater BNS from their child. 
         d. Parents who perceive their child to have lower BNS will use more controlling and less autonomy-supportive practices, which will in turn lead to the report of lower levels of BNS from their child.
registration_responses.q5: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q11: Data for the first time point of the study was already collected by a private research firm in 2019, but we do not have access to it yet. The data from the second time point has not been fully collected yet. We will have access to the whole dataset once the second time point is collected.
registration_responses.q13: The sample size for the second study was fixed at 400 parent-child dyads (800 individuals) for the first time point. We aimed to recruit equal numbers of male and female adolescents.
registration_responses.q14: The sample size was chosen to recruit as many participants as allowed by the funding received to run the study. The funding allowed the recruitment of 400 dyads at T1. We also considered the possible loss of participants between the two time points. Based on our first study, we expect an attrition rate of 25% between the first and second time points which would give us an anticipated total of 300 dyads at T2.
registration_responses.q21: For all analyses, we will use the following indices to judge the fit of our models: the Root Mean Square Error of Approximation (RMSEA), the Standardised Root Mean Square Residual (SRMR), the Comparative Fit Index (CFI), and the Tucker-Lewis Index (TLI). For a good fit, the RMSEA and the SRMR should be lower than .08, and the CFI and TLI should be over .90 (Little, 2013). To judge the significance of our betas, we will also use the standard .05 threshold for p-values.
registration_responses.q23: We will use full-information likelihood to manage all missing data.
registration_responses.q24: We will also test the mediation of the associations with the measure of autonomy-supportive and controlling practices reported by the parents.
registration_responses.q25:
References

Cole, D. A., & Maxwell, S. E. (2003). Testing Mediational Models With Longitudinal Data: Questions and Tips in the Use of Structural Equation Modeling. Journal of Abnormal Psychology, 112(4), 558–577. https://doi.org/10.1037/0021-843X.112.4.558
Deci, E. L., La Guardia, J. G., Moller, A. C., Scheiner, M. J., & Ryan, R. M. (2006). On the Benefits of Giving as Well as Receiving Autonomy Support: Mutuality in Close Friendships. Personality and Social Psychology Bulletin, 32(3), 313–327. https://doi.org/10.1177/0146167205282148
Little, T. D. (2013). Longitudinal structural equation modeling. The Guildford Press.
Little, T. D., Preacher, K. J., Selig, J. P., & Card, N. A. (2007). New developments in latent variable panel analyses of longitudinal data. International Journal of Behavioral Development, 31(4), 357–365. https://doi.org/10.1177/0165025407077757
Mageau, G. A., Ranger, F., Joussemet, M., Koestner, R., Moreau, E., & Forest, J. (2015). Validation of the Perceived Parental Autonomy Support Scale (P-PASS). Canadian Journal of Behavioural Science / Revue Canadienne Des Sciences Du Comportement, 47(3), 251–262. https://doi.org/10.1037/a0039325
Nishimura, T., & Suzuki, T. (2016). Basic Psychological Need Satisfaction and Frustration in Japan: Controlling for the Big Five Personality Traits. Japanese Psychological Research, 58(4), 320–331. https://doi.org/10.1111/jpr.12131
Ohtani, K., Murayama, K., Ishii, R., Fukuzumi, N., Sakaki, M., Ishikawa, S., Suzuki, T., & Tanaka, A. (2019). Parental Motivational Perseverance Predicts Adolescents’ Depressive Symptoms: An Intergenerational Analysis with Actor-Partner Interdependence Model. Journal of Youth and Adolescence. https://doi.org/10.1007/s10964-019-01083-2
Patrick, H., Knee, C. R., Canevello, A., & Lonsbary, C. (2007). The role of need fulfillment in relationship functioning and well-being: A self-determination theory perspective. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, 92(3), 434–457. https://doi.org/10.1037/0022-3514.92.3.434
R Core Team. (2018). R: A Language and Environment for Statistical Computing. R Foundation for Statistical Computing. https://www.R-project.org
Roth, G., Assor, A., Kanat-Maymon, Y., & Kaplan, H. (2007). Autonomous motivation for teaching: How self-determined teaching may lead to self-determined learning. Journal of Educational Psychology, 99(4), 761–774. https://doi.org/10.1037/0022-0663.99.4.761
Ryan, R. M., & Deci, E. L. (2017). Self-determination theory: Basic psychological needs in motivation, development, and wellness. The Guildford Press.
Skinner, E. A., & Belmont, M. J. (1993). Motivation in the classroom: Reciprocal effects of teacher behavior and student engagement across the school year. Journal of Educational Psychology, 85(4), 571–581. https://doi.org/10.1037/0022-0663.85.4.571
Weinstein, N., Przybylski, A. K., & Murayama, K. (2017). A prospective study of the motivational and health dynamics of Internet Gaming Disorder. PeerJ, 5, e3838. https://doi.org/10.7717/peerj.3838
Wuyts, D., Soenens, B., Vansteenkiste, M., & Van Petegem, S. (2018). The role of observed autonomy support, reciprocity, and need satisfaction in adolescent disclosure about friends. Journal of Adolescence, 65, 141–154. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.adolescence.2018.03.012
registration_responses.q8.question: Longitudinal observational study with two time points.
registration_responses.q12.question: Participants were recruited from a large nationwide database managed by a private Japanese research firm. The database includes participants recruited through nationwide newspapers and news magazines ads. Participants were randomly selected from different parts of Japan, with no regional restrictions. Children needed to be between 13 and 15 years of age. The project was explained over the phone to parents and consent was obtained for their own and their child’s participation. Participants were mailed their first questionnaire in October 2019 (T1) and asked to return them. They will be mailed a second questionnaire in February-March 2020 (T2) to return once completed. Parents and adolescents were and will be instructed to fill out their questionnaire independently and not to look at each other’s answers. All participants receive monetary compensation for their participation.
registration_responses.q17.question:
Basic Psychological Need Satisfaction. Parents reported their own and their child’s level of basic psychological need satisfaction by answering the satisfaction subscale from the Japanese version of the Basic Psychological Need Satisfaction and Frustration Scale (Nishimura & Suzuki, 2016) twice – once about themselves and once about their perception of their child’s need satisfaction. Adolescents reported their own need satisfaction by filling out the same scale. The scale contains four items for the satisfaction of each basic psychological need: competence (e.g., “I feel confident that I can do things well”), autonomy (e.g., “I feel my choices express who I really am”), and relatedness (e.g., “I feel connected with the people who care for me, and for whom I care”). The items are answered on a 5-point Likert scale, going from “1 – Completely disagree” to “5 – Completely agree”. 

Parental Autonomy Support and Control. Children reported their perception of their parents’ autonomy support and control by filling out a Japanese translation of the Perceived Parental Autonomy Support Scale (P-PASS; Mageau et al., 2015). Parents also reported their own autonomy-supportive or controlling practices with their child by filling out the same questionnaire. The P-PASS contains 12 items about autonomy support (e.g., “My parents encouraged me to be myself”) and 12 items about psychological control (e.g., “My parents used guilt to control me”). The items are answered on a 7-point Likert scale, going from “1 – Do not agree at all” to “7 – Very strongly agree”.

Family Socioeconomic Status. Parents reported the annual income of the family at T1 by answering one homemade question. 

Sex. Parents and adolescents reported their own sex at T1 by answering one homemade question.

Age. Parents reported their age on a homemade question at T1. Adolescents reported their date of birth at T1, from which their age was calculated.
registration_responses.q18.question: The items of each scale or subscale will be combined into latent variables in the statistical models.
registration_responses.q19.question: All analyses will be performed with the statistical software R (R Core Team, 2018). To answer our three hypotheses, we will run cross-lagged models with mediations in which parents’ BNS, their perception of their child’s BNS, and their child’s self-reported BNS at T1 will predict the same variables at T2. The mediation analyses in our cross-lagged models will test the mediation effect of autonomy-supportive and controlling practices as reported by the children on the associations between parents’ BNS and children’s BNS, and the associations between parents’ perception of their child’s BNS and their child’s self-reported BNS. We will follow the analytic strategy described by Cole and Maxwell (2003) and Little et al. (2007), and applied in Weinstein et al. (2017) and Ohtani et al. (2019), to run mediation analyses in two-waves datasets. We will run a separate model for each basic psychological need, for a total of three models with equality constraints across time points and informants. For each model, we will also control for family socioeconomic status, as well as the age and sex of parents and adolescents.

attributes.title: Stage1_Registered_Report
attributes.description: This component contains the approved protocol of this registered report, as well as the exploratory data reported in the stage 1 registered report.

q1.value: Cultural pressure and biased responding in free will attitudes

q2.value: David Wisniewski, Senne Braem, Ian Hussey, Emiel Cracco, Carlos González-García

q3.value: I confirm this study has been granted in-principle acceptance.

q8.value: This preregistration includes the approved protocol, as well as the revision history of the submitted stage 1 manuscript from Royal Society Open Science.

registration_responses.q1: Cultural pressure and biased responding in free will attitudes
registration_responses.q3: I confirm this study has been granted in-principle acceptance.
registration_responses.q8: This preregistration includes the approved protocol, as well as the revision history of the submitted stage 1 manuscript from Royal Society Open Science.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Evaluations of Politicians - this study examines the role of warmth, competence and political skills in evaluations of male and female candidates in the United States Democratic Primary.

other.value: We will also be assessing participants' view on women in politics, ambivalent sexism, religiosity, and right-wing authoritarianism for exploratory purposes.

sample.value: 285 participants will be recruited from Prolific Academic.

analyses.value:
Non-linear regression analysis comparing 2 curves (male condition vs. female condition).
Comparison of trait/evaluation correlations above and below the mean.

dependent.value: Participants will be asked to rate how well this politician represents their interests from 1 (not at all) to 5 (very much), how qualified they are to be president from 1 (not at all qualified) to 5 (very qualified), and how much they like this politician as a person from 1 (dislike a great deal) to 5 (like a great deal). They will then be asked to assess the politician's electoral chances from 1 (very low) to 5 (very high) in both the Democratic primary and the general election, and to indicate how willing they would be to vote for this politician both a) given their electoral chances and then b) if they did not have to take their electoral chances into account, on a scale from 1 (not at all willing) to 5 (very willing).

conditions.value: 2 conditions - participants will be randomly assigned to either a male politician or female politician condition.

hypothesis.value: There will be a significant positive relationship between the trait ratings (warmth, competence, and political skills) of female politicians and their evaluations by participants such that women who are deemed warmer, more competent and in possession of greater political skills will be evaluated significantly more positively than their female colleagues who lack these qualities. This effect will occur also for male politicians, but will be weaker. Further, we expect different non-linear relationships between trait ratings and overall evaluations of politicians. Specifically, as the trait ratings of female politicians increases, we expect it to relate less strongly to overall ratings. This reflects a pattern where women are rated unfavourably when they are perceived to lack desirable traits, but not to be rated especially favourably when they possess them. In contrast, we expect the correlation between traits and overall evaluation of male politicians to strengthen as trait ratings increase. This reflects a pattern where men are not particularly derogated for lacking desirable traits, but are valorized when they possess them more than expected.

They will then be asked to assess the politician's electoral chances from 1 (very low) to 5 (very high) in both the Democratic primary and the general election, and to indicate how willing they would be to vote for this politician both a) given their electoral chances and then b) if they did not have to take their electoral chances into account, on a scale from 1 (not at all willing) to 5 (very willing).

This effect will occur also for male politicians, but will be weaker. Further, we expect different non-linear relationships between trait ratings and overall evaluations of politicians. Specifically, as the trait ratings of female politicians increases, we expect it to relate less strongly to overall ratings. This reflects a pattern where women are rated unfavourably when they are perceived to lack desirable traits, but not to be rated especially favourably when they possess them. In contrast, we expect the correlation between traits and overall evaluation of male politicians to strengthen as trait ratings increase. This reflects a pattern where men are not particularly derogated for lacking desirable traits, but are valorized when they possess them more than expected.

attributes.title: Income Mobility and Tolerance for Income Inequality: Spanish Evidence
attributes.description:
An experimental study will be carried out in order to test the idea that perceptions of income mobility have a positive effect on tolerance towards economic inequality.  This is a replica of the study that Shariff, Wiwad and Aknin (2016) conducted in The United States. The only differences that distinguish the current research from the one mentioned above are that the target population is altered to be people with the Spanish nationality and that another dependent variable is introduced: attitudes towards income redistribution through taxes.

In short, we predict that participants in the high (vs the low) mobility condition will show a) greater tolerance toward inequality, b) less support for redistribution through taxes.

q1.value: Income Mobility and Tolerance for Income Inequality: Spanish Evidence

q2.value: Águeda Fuentes-Guerra Toral, Guillermo B. Willis

q3.value: An experimental study will be carried out in order to test the idea that perceptions of income mobility have a positive effect on tolerance towards economic inequality. This is a replica of the study that Shariff, Wiwad, and Aknin (2016) conducted in The United States. The only differences that distinguish the current research from the one mentioned above are that the target population is altered to be people with the Spanish nationality and that another dependent variable is introduced: attitudes towards income redistribution through taxes.

q4.value: We predict that participants in the high (vs the low) mobility condition will show a) greater tolerance toward inequality, b) less support for redistribution through taxes.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: Between subjects with 1 factor (perceptions of income mobility) and 2 levels (high and low), multivariate (1. tolerance towards economic inequality and 2. support for redistribution through taxes) design with one mediator variable (trust in the government).

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited through a qualtrics link provided via social media. The participation in this experiment is voluntary. Participants must have Spanish Nationality and be at least 18 years old and not be older than 40 years old.

q13.value: The target is 300 participants, therefore I will try to recruit as many people as I can, assuming that not every questionnaire will be valid.

question.value:
The perception of income mobility will be manipulated in two levels through a news article. 
1. High perception of income mobility
2. Low perception of income mobility

Tolerance towards inequality will be measured by asking participants how much do they agree or disagree on a scale of 1-7 to the following affirmations (being 1-totally disagree, 2-strongly disagree, 3-at odds, 4-neither agree nor disagree, 5-agree, 6-strongly agree, 7-totally agree). 
-I think that the current income inequality in Spain is unacceptable
-I think that the income inequality state in Spain is unjust. 
-I think that income inequality is one of the biggest problems that Spain is facing right now. 

Support for redistribution through taxes will be measured by a qualitative meter of a face with 5 levels (totally dislike, dislike, neutral, like and totally like).

Trust in the government will be measured by asking participants how much do they agree or disagree on a scale of 1-7 to the following affirmations (being 1-totally disagree, 2-strongly disagree, 3-at odds, 4-neither agree nor disagree, 5-agree, 6-strongly agree, 7-totally agree).
-I think the Spanish government is trustworthy.
-I believe that the Spanish government is selfless and works fully for the happiness and wellbeing of the Spanish. 
-I think the Spanish government is corrupted.
We will test these hypotheses using three independent samples three tests.

attributes.title: Traumatic dental injuries are greater in person that use alcohol or illicit drugs, than in those non users? A systematic review

summary.value: This is a registration project of a study that aims to evaluate the association between use of drugs/alcohol and dental trauma. The data collection did not begin. The attached files contain the methodological plain.
